page.title: 07A HISTORIC INN
page.content: {UNCLE TOM'S CABIN} This inn was the centre of amusement before the famous Winter Gardens were built, and is still a popular landmark today. The original cabin was built in the early 19th century by Thomas Parkinson, who was known as "Uncle Tom". It stood 100 feet above the cliffs to the north of Blackpool and was a well-known meeting place, selling toffee and ginger beer. It was sold to a Mr. Taylor for Â£5. A story says that around this time the book "Uncle Tom's Cabin" was written, and a negro bust from a ship's figurehead was washed up on to the shore near to the inn. The bust was hung up with a sign showing the inn's new name. The original inn was demolished as the coastline retreated but the present cabin stands nearby.
